channel.title: Whats the Difference

item.title: Whats the Difference
item.dc:creator: @meiscooldude meiscooldude
item.description:
@meiscooldude wrote:

one would think the method names would help hint to its purpose… but NOoooOOOooo…

lol, jk

Both methods ‘equalsIgnoreCase(String)’ and ‘startsWith(String)’ return a boolean

They are both methods of the String class,

Strings are as follows:

“Hello world”
“Meiscooldude”
“Jeff Dunham”
“Simple String”

Anything in quotes, you can create strings like so:

//when initializing an object, its constructor is called…
String str = new String(new char[] {‘H’, ‘e’, ‘l’, ‘l’ ‘o’, ’ ', ‘W’, ‘o’, ‘r’, ‘l’, ‘d’, ‘!’ });

Or you can do it the simple way, like so:

String str = “Hello world”;

Java’s compiler is SOO fucking smart, that when it sees something in quotes, it auto-magically makes it into a String object!

(Note, Strings are immutable, meaning, THEY CANNOT BE CHANGED!, w/e you THINK you changing a String, you are actually just creating a new one and replacing the old one w/ it!)

Anyway, to your question…

Since String is an object, it does have methods, like… lol, equals, to check if the strings equal eachother (YOU CANNOT USE ==, that doesnt check by value, only be reference! yaddadadada…)

just…

in short…

.equalsIgnoreCase(“hello”) returns whether or not it equals the command with case being ignored…

.startsWith(“hel”) returns whether or not the string STARTS WITH the argument…

… :)… i feel dumb…

Read full topic

item.title: Whats the Difference
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

airborne:

The ignore case one means you can type the command in caps, and the startswith one means if your command is starter, and you accidently type ::starter1, starter will still work because the command “starts with” starter.

Incorrect.
[hr]

IgnoreCase means it will ignore if it is in capital letter’s or lowercase letter’s, so if you type “::CMD” it will trigger the command, also if you type “::cmd” it will trigger the command, witch is useful knowing the java programing language is case sensitive.

startsWith means if the command starts with the word “CMD” then it will trigger the command, so you could type “::cmd agafa” and it would still trigger the command.

Read full topic
